docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks to this week's presidential debates forums, town halls, whatever you want to call them -- we now know that Bill Bradley's idea of a great leader is Jimmy Carter (''integrity''), Woodrow Wilson (''the ability to see around corners'') or Mikhail Gorbachev (''courage''). Who could not find this interesting? Once again, Mr. Bradley demonstrated that he is a new kind of candidate, a man who skips the predictable tributes to Lincoln and F.D.R., and instead names three former heads of state so high-minded their constituents practically ran them out of town on a rail. How many of you watched the debates on TV? (I don't want to see any hands from people who taped. Sure, you're going to watch them later, right after all six hours of ''Middlemarch.'') No matter. We'll boil them down for you. We have nothing better to do with our time -- in fact, we can travel right up to New Hampshire and watch them on the spot, in a large hall where people are not permitted to click over to the Weather Channel when Steve Forbes starts explaining his economic agenda.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column on impressions of first campaign debate between Al Gore and Bill Bradley; reports Gore, inviting extra questions, resembled kid asking teacher for more homework, while Bradley, lounging on his stool, looked like high school athlete watching class nerd volunteer to stay and clap erasers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Armenian Gunmen Give Up And Face Terror Charges Armenian prosecutors brought terrorism charges against three of five gunmen who seized the Parliament on Wednesday, killing eight people and taking 40 hostages. The gunmen gave up the last of their hostages after nightlong negotiations. A12 Outlawed Sect Appeals for Help Members of the Falun Gong spiritual movement met with a handful of foreign journalists in Beijing to appeal for international help against a Chinese Government crackdown. docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore ripped apart Bill Bradley's health care proposal today, saying it cost too much, in part because it would provide insurance even for the wealthy, and would swallow up the entire budget surplus. ''It may be a big idea, but it's not a good idea,'' Mr. Gore declared, offering a riposte to Mr. Bradley's assertion in their first one-on-one appearance Wednesday night that health insurance was a big problem that needed a big solution. ''Alchemy was a big idea, but it wasn't a good idea.''

headline.main: Gore Steps Up the Attack Against Bradley on Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Economy Expands Briskly, With Labor Costs Benign The American economy turned in its best quarterly performance of the year this summer, expanding at a brisk 4.8 percent annual rate. That virtually guaranteed enough momentum to carry the nation to its longest economic expansion in history early next year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance companies in New York are starting to pay as much for prescription drugs as they pay for care of hospitalized patients, a stunning change in direction for the region's health care dollars. The effects of these rising drug costs are felt at every point, from the manufacturers battling with Congress and the White House to the doctor pressured to prescribe a drug preferred by a health maintenance organization to the shopper at the pharmacy counter who learns that her asthma medication will cost twice as much as it did last month.

headline.main: Rising Costs of Medications Take Bigger Share of Insurance Outlays

docs.abstract: Health insurance companies in New York are starting to pay as much for prescription drugs as they pay for care of hospitalized patients, a stunning change in direction for region's health care dollars; effects of these rising drug costs are felt at every point, from manufacturers battling with Congress and White House to doctor pressured to prescribe a drug preferred by health maintenance orgn to shopper who learns that his asthma medication will cost twice as much as it did last month; for the insurance industry, shift in health care costs is prompting health maintenance orgns to change ways patients pay for drugs, and in some cases, passing on the increase directly to consumers, or trying to persuade hospitals to absorb some of new burden; some employers, faced with rising premiums, are requiring workers to pay 20 percent of each prescription, rather than continuing practice of a fixed co-payment (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Clinton's proposals to protect the privacy of health records (front page, Oct. 27) miss the mark on mental health. Patients in psychotherapy need to have their privacy and the confidentiality of their sessions protected. They should never have to sign over these rights to receive insurance benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Given their assets and handicaps, Vice President Gore and Bill Bradley came off quite nicely in their first television whatever. But the questioners in the New Hampshire audience, so well educated and well mannered, did themselves no credit. Perhaps the process of becoming so well mannered and well educated had boiled out of them all interest in human beings except themselves and their families.

headline.main: On My Mind; The Great Encounter

docs.abstract: A M Rosenthal Op-Ed column on campaign debate in New Hampshire observes that Bill Bradley's great asset is that he does not remind voters of Bill Clinton, while Al Gore's handicap is that he does; adds that audience, so well educated and well mannered, did themselves no credit, since they seemed to have little interest in world issues that do not directly affect themselves (S)
docs.snippet: Given their assets and handicaps, Vice President Gore and Bill Bradley came off quite nicely in their first television whatever. But the questioners in the New Hampshire audience, so well educated and well mannered, did themselves no credit.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association and six other medical societies said yesterday that they had created an Internet company that, starting next year, will publish consumer information on health care and help doctors set up their own medical Web sites to communicate with patients by E-mail. Medem Inc., a for-profit company, enters a crowded field of Internet medical information companies that includes DrKoop.com, Healtheon and Medscape, as well as 17,000 other World Wide Web sites devoted to health care information.

headline.main: A.M.A. and 6 Others Set Up Medical Internet Company

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a Republican Presidential candidates' forum last night involving Gary L. Bauer, former president of the Family Research Council; the publisher Steve Forbes; Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah; Alan Keyes, a radio commentator and former Assistant Secretary of State, and Senator John McCain of Arizona, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency. The candidates answered questions from an audience at Dartmouth College, in Hanover, N.H. Q. Should the Republican Party be more inclusive by encouraging pro-choice voters to support their candidates?

headline.main: Excerpts From the Five Republican Candidates' Debate at Dartmouth
